37 EVAM
Evaporative system monitoring

EVAM, EVAM General
37.1 EVAM General
� General Information
Environment protection is one of the main focuses of past and future automotive development. The protection
of the environment is enforced by law which is mainly driven by the US- CARB (California Air Research
Board), an US government agency. The focus on these laws is to restrict the amount of environmentally
harmful (exhaust) gases that are released to the atmosphere when vehicles equipped with combustion
engines are in operation. To monitor the related parts on a vehicle that are prone to let evaporate gases to
the environment a certain software logic (EVAM) is provided on the Engine Control Unit.
1. Introduction to EVAM
On gasoline combustion engines, several exhaust gases are produced like CO, NOx, CO2, H2O and HCs
(hydrocarbons). HCs not only emerge from incomplete fuel combustion in the engine, but also from the
tank system, so before the actual usage of the fuel. This is due to the fact that gasoline, in contrast to
Diesel fuel, has a lower heat of evaporation which leads, especially in warm and hot ambient conditions,
to relatively high amounts of evaporated hydrocarbons, that would, in an open system, normally escape
to the environment. To avoid the escaping of these gases and therefore to be in accordance with the law,
the fuel tank and the pipes that built-up the fuel tank system, must be monitored during the whole vehicle
lifetime. Leaks must be detected on board. That means an algorithm on the engine control unit must
check the tightness of the fuel tank system on a regular basis (- ->on board diagnosis, OBD). This tank leak
check of the fuel tank system is one part of Evaporative system Monitoring (EVAM) function.
Figure 37.1.1: Simpli?ed overview of fuel tank system (and engine)
As high amounts of evaporated hydrocarbons, on the one hand, can not be kept inside the tank system
because of the risk of tank bursting, they can not, on the other hand, be let out to the ambience because of

Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

EVAM, EVAM General
legal restrictions, environment protection and fuel economy reasons. Due to this fact, an Active Char Coal
Filter (ACF) is used on the vehicle to collect these amounts of evaporated fuel gases. This ACF, located in a
canister, works like a sponge which accumulates all the HCs that are evaporated inside the tank system. The
accumulated gases are ?released? again when the engine is running and avalve, located between engine
manifold and ACF, is opened. The pressure difference between the engine manifold and the ambience
provokes an air ?ow from outside (so from ambience) through the ACF and the valve to the engine. The
air?ow takes along the HCs from the ACF and purges them into the engine manifold.
The mechanical function check (or plausibility check) of this electrically driven valve that builds the link
between engine manifold, ACF and ambience, is the other part of the Evaporative System Monitoring
(EVAM) function. As the actual function of this valve is purging of gases from the ACF to the engine
manifold, this test is called the CPS-Check. ( CPS means Canister Purge Solenoid) This check has to be
done on a regular basis as the ACF has a limited hydrocarbon storage capability which means, that once
the ACF is full and the CPS is e.g. stuck closed, no hydrocarbons can be purged into the engine manifold.
These gases would then escape to the environment as an additional mechanical overpressure valve, which
is located in the tank system for safety reasons, would open.
Background information concerning formal legal requirements
In the European Union, neither the CPS-Check nor the tank tightness check are required. In 2011, these
checks are necessary for the United States, Korea, Japan and some other countries. In the United States, it
is required to detect large Leaks (>1mm) and small leaks (>0.5 mm) whereas the large leak check has to
run clearly more often than the small leak check. This originates from different ratio requirement which is
explained below.
As failures from EVAM diagnostics - so detected leaks or a stuck CPS valve - are OBD (so emission) rele-
vant, these failures must illuminate the MIL (Mal function Indication Lamp or check engine lamp) in the
instrument cluster after the same failure has occurred during several subsequent driving cycles. This illu-
mination should ?tell? the driver to go to the garage. (The way when and how the MIL should be illuminated
is de?ned in the error management).
Also, due to the OBD relevance, it is required to record the frequency of each diagnostic. That means, it has
to be recorded how often the check (for the tank leak or the CPS valve) has actuallyrun during a certain
number of vehicle driving cycles. This number has to be compared to the number of driving cycles where
the check could have run, which gives for each diagnostic instance a certain ratio. CARB requirement for
CPS-check and large leak check are ratios greater than 0.52 and greater than 0.26 for small leak detections.
This ratio building is handled in the RBM (Rate Based Monitoring) functionality which is fed with inputs
from EVAM. (Depending on how trivial the calculation for RBM is, the feeding might not be necessary but
could be done in the error management itself. But this requires error manager 6 and higher, too.)
Furthermore, for each of the EVAM diagnostics so called Mode6 values (or SAE-values) have to be pro-
vided. These values are calculated at the end of the diagnosis and the values used are the ones from the
physical criteria that lead to the ?nal diagnostic result. Mode6 value calculation occurs in failure and in
non-failure case and consists of the currently measured, the maximum allowed and the minimum allowed
value. The results must be accessible by an external scan-tool using the OBD interface connector on the
vehicle.

These values are calculated at the end of the diagnosis and the values used are the ones from the
physical criteria that lead to the ?nal diagnostic result. Mode6 value calculation occurs in failure and in
non-failure case and consists of the currently measured, the maximum allowed and the minimum allowed
value. The results must be accessible by an external scan-tool using the OBD interface connector on the
vehicle.
In case of other system failures detected by the engine control unit (ECU) which might lead to wrong re-
sults during the CPS-Check or the tank leak check, the diagnostics are inhibited.
One important item that EVAM diagnostics need to prove during development phase and for ?nal certi-
?cation, is that both checks, so the CPS-Check and the tank leak check, do run at least once during the
of?cial FTP (Federal Test Procedure) -cycle which is a special vehicle driving cycle where certain require-
ments, like emissions, fuel consumption, etc., need to be ful?lled to get the certi?cation from government
agencies.
2. General description of detection methods used in EVAM functionality

EVAM, EVAM General
After a short introduction to the general requirements that EVAM needs to ful?l, the general methods that
are used to meet these requirements are explained in this chapter. For the two EVAM tasks, several possible
methods are usable:
Tank leak check
? Creation of vacuum inside the tank system and monitoring the stability of this vacuum for a certain pe-
riod or time, or monitoring the duration of time till a certain vacuum is built-up
? Creation of overpressure inside the tank system and monitoring the duration of time till a certain over-
pressure is built-up
Some of these leak detection methods run while engine is running, some when engine is off and some
when engine and ECU are off.
Canister Purge Solenoid Plausibility-Check (CPS-Check)
? By actuation, so opening and closing, of the CPS valve, a certain (air + hydrocarbon) ?ow is generated
into the engine manifold which leads to a reaction on some other system parameters like the value of
the controller for the O2-Sensor, the manifold air pressure sensor value, the throttle position and so on.
The presence or the non-presence of this reaction is used to detect the functional status of the canister
purge solenoid valve
? Another method, which is only a small variation of the just presented method, is the way to also actu-
ate the CPS valve but this time the induced interference is compensated inside the air path / injection
aggregate and the degree of compensation gives evidence about the functional status of the valve. The
big advantage of this method is principally on the comfort side as the CPS-check will not be felt by the
driver.
? A third way of a functional check of the CPS valve is to use the overpressure (or vacuum) generated
during the leak check. When a certain overpressure (or vacuum) is reached and the CPS is opened, the
pressure difference should vanish.
All these different CPS-checks are performed when engine is running. Some can only run when engine
is in a stable phase like idle speed, some can also run when engine is running in part load. Due to
fuel economy reasons, idle speed phases of vehicles are more and more reduced which leads to the
preference of detection methods running in part load.
3. Tank leak detection and CPS-check methods de?ned within this aggregate
As mentioned in the previous chapter, there are several ways to run diagnostics for the tank leak and
the plausibility of the CPS valve. The following subchapters (3.x) describe the methods used within this
aggregate.
3.1 Tank Leak detection by Natural Vacuum Leak Detection (NVLD)
In this (software) aggregate Natural Vacuum Leak Detection (NVLD) is used. The way NVLD diagnostic
physically works is described in chapter 3.1.1. The subsequent chapter, 3.1.2, gives an overview about the
important features and their realization in the ECU software. Chapter 3.1.3 explains brie?y all NVLD diagnos-
tic instances and chapter 3.1.4 lists the whole state ?ow of a diagnosis cycle in (condensed) pseudo code
format.
3.1.1 Short introduction to the physics used for the tank tightness check by NVLD

Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

EVAM, EVAM General
Tank leak detection by NVLD method basically uses the small pressure differences that occur naturally in
the tank when vehicles are in operation. So it uses the vacuum tank leak detection method like mentioned
before.
During the day (or night), when a vehicle is parked, the fuel in the tank is exposed to the temperature of
the ambient air, the heat emission from the exhaust pipes and also the heat emission from the ground.
Depending on the absolute gradient of all these temperatures that affect the temperature of the fuel in the
tank, the pressure in the tank increases or decreases. This means, that when temperature gradient is positive,
the fuel in the tank heats up and more fuel gases evaporate which leads to an increase of the pressure in
the tank. (As there is an ACF and a safety valve mounted on the tank system, the HCs get collected in the
ACF and the air/pressure gets released to the ambient. So normally, as long as the ACF is not full, no HCs
escape to the environment and the pressure in the tank stays around ambient). When the gradient gets
negative during the day, so the temperature starts getting lower within a certain delay, the temperatures in
the tank system do also decrease which leads to a lower pressure in the tank. Too low tank pressure might
damage the tank physically that?s why there is also a second mechanical safety valve in the tank system that
prevents the pressure in the tank getting too low by simply opening at a certain level and letting in fresh air
from the outside. But this threshold is clearly lower than the pressure levels used for NVLD.
The NVLD module, which is mounted close to the ACF, detects this pressure decrease by a simple pressure
sensor in the module that consists basically of a diaphragm combined with a mechanical switch which
closes from a certain vacuum level on ( <-2.5hPa) when the diaphragm is lifted up and presses the switch
against an electric pin. So NVLD does not measure the value of the pressure in the tank but gets the
information indirectly from the switch-closed position and duration. That means, a temperature decrease,
measured by a NVLD-internal temperature sensor, followed by a closed switch for a certain period of time,
gives clear indication that the tank is tight. On the other hand a fuel tank system with a leak would keep the
pressure in the tank at ambient pressure level and would therefore lead to an open position of the switch.
This kind of tank pressure monitoring with NVLD starts with the "diagnostic mode" at the end of the power
latch phase of the ECU, so when engine is off and ECU is no longer powered. (The exact moment is when
the central state machine in the software, STATE_NVLD, switches to "OFF" in power latch). During the "diag-
nostic mode", the NVLD wakes-up every 10 min for less than a 1 sec and checks certain, relevant parameters.
On the ?rst wake-up of the NVLD, so after 10 min, all parameters are ignored and therefore no measurement
is done. From then on, the acquisition of data begins with the monitoring of the switch position and the am-
bient temperature change with regard to switch opening and temperature increase. The physical principle
behind this is: If the ambient temperature increases, the pressure in the tank must increase as well and as a
consequence the switch must open. Experimental tests showed that a temperature increase of +5�C, with a
presence of at least 60 min, is suf?ciently high enough. When this condition is met, it can be said that the
switch must surely be open. The acquainted data, so switch position and temperature increase, is used for
the switch plausibility diagnosis which has to be done on a regular basis as it has to be assured that the
switch is mechanically working.
The acquisition of data for the small leak diagnosis begins after 60 min (from begin of diagnostic mode) for
the switch position, and after a delay time of 90 min (from begin of diagnostic mode) for the ambient tem-
perature. The ambient temperature from that point in time is stored and is used as a reference temperature.
All other following temperature measurements are compared to this one.

The acquisition of data for the small leak diagnosis begins after 60 min (from begin of diagnostic mode) for
the switch position, and after a delay time of 90 min (from begin of diagnostic mode) for the ambient tem-
perature. The ambient temperature from that point in time is stored and is used as a reference temperature.
All other following temperature measurements are compared to this one. If the temperature decrease gets
higher than 6�C and 8�C (which are also derived from experimental tests) and this decrease is kept for more
than 120 min, then this information is stored in the NVLD. Together with the switch position and the switch
closing time duration, which has to be at minimum 10 min to declare the tank as tight, the small leak test
results are built-up.
The diagnostic mode can last up to max. 24 hours but can also be shorter in case it is interrupted by an
ECU key-on (LV_IGK = 0 - ->1) event. It is also shorter when it has been cancelled by the NVLD itself due to
detection of electrical faults on the switch or on the temperature sensor.
Apart from the ?diagnostic mode? there is also a ?sleepmode? existing for the NVLD smart module. Dur-
ing this mode, no measurements by the NVLD are performed. The ?sleep mode?, in lieu of the ?diagnostic
mode?, usually gets activated on system errors and on too low ambient pressure or ambient temperature
values. So that means, the decision whether NVLD should start a ?sleep mode? or a ?diagnostic mode? is done
at the same time and it is done with the involvement of environment and system condition.
With all the data collected by the NVLD during the diagnostic mode, the ECU control algorithm decides on
next vehicle driving cycle if on the one hand the switch is mechanically ok (= switch plausibility diagnosis)
and on the other hand if a small leak (0.5 mm) is present in the tank or if the tank can be considered as

EVAM, EVAM General
tight.
The monitoring and memorization can be accomplished by the NVLD device as the NVLD is some sort of
a smart module that is equipped with a temperature sensor and a certain computer logic that allows the
acquisition and memorization of parameters necessary for the diagnostic.
As the pressure difference, that evokes the movement of the switch from open to closed, is very small the
whole diagnostic principle is very sensitive to ambient pressure changes. That?s why the results from the
NVLD that are delivered to the ECU on engine start are discarded if the pressure at the beginning of the
diagnostic mode varies too (abs(6,5hPa)) much compared to the one determined on engine start.
When the engine is running and the CPS is opened for general purging purpose or CPS-check, the air ?ow
that is needed for purging is coming from ambient and is going through the NVLD module and the ACF
to the engine manifold. The purge ?ow through the NVLD module is established by a second ?channel?
inside the NVLD that gets opened by a poppet valve which itself gets opened due to the increasing vacuum
created by the purge ?ow.
Figure 37.1.2: System events, ?diagnostic mode? and typical behaviour of parameters
3.1.2 ECU software features and aggregate structure
After this short introduction to the physics, the following chapter will outline which and how data from
physical measurements of the NVLD are made available to the ECU and how this data is processed. So in
the end it means this chapter should brie?y inform the reader about the main features in the ECU software in
combination with the provided data from the NVLD.
The software in the ECU, so the control algorithm of the ECU that enables the gathering of information from
the NVLD and also the sending of data to the NVLD, basically has to accomplish fourthings:
1. Establish communication between NVLD and ECU (<Request>and <Response>)
The communication between NVLD and ECU is realized by a bi-directional line. This means either of them,
so NVLD or ECU, can send and receive messages on this line. The messages are translated into electric
short-cut-to-ground pulses on a ?battery voltage? supplied line. With the pulse duration and the amount of
pulses (in a certain period of time) the exchanged messages are prescribed.
Data from the NVLD, so status ?ags, temperatures or time durations, are requested by the ECU with state
File: 30102A04.00A
10499Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
EVAM, EVAM General
request ?ags that are always built-up in the same way: LV_STATE_REQ_***_NVLD. (The ?***? stands for the
respective, requested information). This state request ?ag is interpreted by a communication state machine,
visible in software with the label STATE_REQ_NVLD, in which the messages are then created. The messages
are translated into electrical pulses (by an electric driver), that can be tracked by checking the behaviour of
the bit LV_DR_OUT_SMT_NVLD. Also, responses from the NVLD are translated back from electrical pulses
into ?physical? variables or status ?ags.
On every response, followed by a request, the ECU gets informed about the validity of the response by the
?ag LV_STATE_RESP_***_VLD_NVLD.
This communication process is described in the module "Smart sensor communication for natural vacuum
leak detection (I09W)".
2. Detect malfunctions in the communication process.
Invalid responses (or no responses at all) from the NVLD need to be identi?ed and reported to the error
manager. This reporting is done with the diagnostic instance "RESP_REP_COMC".
Also, the line itself has to be electrically monitored to guarantee correct communication. Shorts on the line
or open circuits are reported with SMT_EL_SCP/SCG/OC_NVLD and the detection of electrical faults happens
automatically by an electric driver (ATIC). Due to the fact that short cut to grounds are used to send and
receive messages, SCG detection is not possible during communication, so during STATE_COMC = ?REQ? or
?RESP?.
RESP_REP_COMC errors are generated in "Smart sensor communication for natural vacuum leak detec-
tion (I09W)" whereas the electrical monitoring is done in " Electrical diagnosis communication line NVLD"
(A0MP).
(The diagnostic instance REQ_REP_EL_NVLD is not used).
3. Evaluation of all parameters necessary for a valid SMALL_LEAK diagnosis
After a system start (key-on & engine start) from ECU-off, the state ?ow of the central state machine (STATE_
NVLD) in the ECU software is always processed in the same way. That means it always goes through the
same states and requests data from the NVLD that was collected during the previous diagnostic mode. Nor-
mally ?fteen seconds (the time is derived from the number of requests (9) multiplied by time that is needed
to process a request (?1,5 sec)) after engine start, it will reach the state (STATE_NVLD = ?SMALL_LEAK_DIAG?),
where all necessary parameters for small leak diagnosis are checked at the end of this state. On this check
result, the decision is done whether a valid small leak diagnosis result is present or not. These parameter
checks consists on the one hand of a simple compare of ambient pressure at engine start to the last mea-
sured ambient pressure before ECU power off. On the other hand it consists of parameters from the NVLD
that have been gathered and analysed in special ECU software features. These features are all processed
before the end of the state "SMALL_LEAK_DIAG". They are described below in the subitems a) - f).
(The precise state ?ow with the requests can be looked up in NVLD plausibility diagnosis manager (B09G)
or in chapter 3.1.4).Only in power latch, the requests are set independently from the central state machine.
For more details on this, see NVLD plausibility diagnosis check (B09H)).
a) NVLD TemperatureSensor Value Cross Check
The NVLD is equipped with a ambient temperature sensor that delivers on ECU request (which is set with
LV_STATE_REQ_TAM_SMT_NVLD = 1) thecurrent temperature value (TAM_SMT_NVLD) present at the NVLD
module. On cold start this value has to be in the same range like TCO and TIA sensors that are installed
on the system.

a) NVLD TemperatureSensor Value Cross Check
The NVLD is equipped with a ambient temperature sensor that delivers on ECU request (which is set with
LV_STATE_REQ_TAM_SMT_NVLD = 1) thecurrent temperature value (TAM_SMT_NVLD) present at the NVLD
module. On cold start this value has to be in the same range like TCO and TIA sensors that are installed
on the system. If not, a failure TAM_SMT_CHK is set and an existing small leak result is discarded.- - >
LV_INH_DIAG_SMALL_LEAK_NVLD = 1
b) TAM_SMT_RNG_H/L and TAM_SMT_PLAUS diagnostic
During ?diagnostic mode?, the NVLD wakes-up every 10 minutes and makes a range check of the TAM_
SMT_NVLD sensor value. If the value is too low (RNG_L) or too high (RNG_H) or the value did change
too much in between two measurements (PLAUS) the NVLD stores this information and stops diagnostic
mode (on its own). On next engine start, this data is provided on request (during STATE_NVLD = "READ_
INI") to the ECU and gets analysed. If the analysis leads to an error, small leak results are discarded. - - >
LV_INH_DIAG_SMALL_LEAK_NVLD = 1.
TAM_SMT sensor diagnostics, so items a) and b) are done in the module Plausibility diagnosis of smart
module temperature sensor (B0BR).

EVAM, EVAM General
TAM_SMT_CHK and TAM_SMT_RNG_L diagnostics are only done on cold start and when the diagnostics
for TCO and TIA sensor are ?nished. (For de?nition of cold start and TCO/TIA diagnosis-end see Evapora-
tive system monitoring for NVLD (Appl. Inc.) (B09B))
TAM_SMT_RNG_H and TAM_SMT_PLAUS are done on hot start as well. Additionally TAM_SMT_RNG_H is
checked ?continuously? during engine running. (?- ->OBD relevant sensors need to be monitored continu-
ously on their electrical status. CARB requirement).
For more info about the exact failure criteria see descriptions of TAM_SMT failures in chapter 3.1.4
c) Switch Electrical Diagnosis
Like mentioned in chapter 3.1.1, the pressure in the tank is measured indirectly by a switch. The electrical
status of the switch needs to be checked in order to be able to declare the switch position as trustworthy
and therefore later on also the small leak result. The electrical status of the switch is determined by the
NVLD but the evaluation of the electrical status, so the diagnostic, is done by the ECU. All electrical status
?ags, so the SCP/SCG and OC information, are gathered on request (during STATE_NVLD = "TAM_SWI_
DIAG") and analysed in the module Electrical diagnosis NVLD (A0ML).
Typically, the ?rst check of the switch electrical status is done before Small Leak Diagnosis since a negative
switch electrical result will lead to the discarding of existing small leak results (- - >LV_INH_DIAG_SMALL_
LEAK_NVLD = 1). Also, as electrical diagnostics have to be carried out continuously (- - >same OBD re-
quirement as for TAM_SMT_RNG_H), the electrical status is also checked on a cyclical basis while engine is
running.
d)Detection of Smart Module Resets (occurred diagnostic mode)
While NVLD is in ?diagnostic mode?, it always has to be supplied by battery voltage. If the battery voltage
drops below a certain level, NVLD is reset. A respective status bit is set and the "diagnostic mode" is
stopped. That means, no small leak test results will be available on next engine running phase / driving
cycle.
To inform the system if anything went wrong during ?diagnostic mode? concerning the voltage supply,
this reset information bit (LV_RST_SMT_NVLD) is carried out on next vehicle driving cycle during STATE_
NVLD = "READ_INI". In case the bit was set, an error RST_SMT_NVLD is generated during the subsequent
diagnosis. Like Switch Electric or TAM_SMT sensor diagnostic faults a RST_SMT fault will also inhibit the
small leak diagnosis: LV_INH_DIAG_SMALL_LEAK_NVLD will be set.
This diagnostic is done in NVLD plausibility diagnosis manager (B09G)
e) Monitoring of the mechanical status of the switch
In order to be able to decide whether a small leak is existing in the fuel tank system, the switch position
during ?diagnostic mode? is the key information. A closed switch signalizes a tight system, whereas an
open switch would indicate a leak in the fuel tank system. But the switch could also be closed not because
of a vacuum in the tank but because of some mechanical issues that lead to a closed stuck switch. To
exclude this aspect, a switch rationality check, which is also named plausibility or mechanical check, has to
be done before small leak check on Turbo engines (ii) and before the beginning of the ?diagnostic mode?
on non-turbo engines (i).
i) Switch check for non-turbo engines
For non-turbo engines, the check for the correct mechanical functioning of the switch is performed in
power latch before the start of ?diagnostic mode?.

on non-turbo engines (i).
i) Switch check for non-turbo engines
For non-turbo engines, the check for the correct mechanical functioning of the switch is performed in
power latch before the start of ?diagnostic mode?. The test is possible if the switch was closed during the
whole previous engine running phase prior to the power latch or if the switch was open before engine
start and closed during the subsequent engine running phase due to the vacuum creation in the tank by
the purge ?ow through the canister purge valve. A switch mechanical check is not possible if the switch
was permanently open. (A permanently open switch will eventually lead to a small leak error result which
will lead, in case there was no leak detectable after a inspection in the garage, to an exchange of the
NVLD module). Normally, this switch check begins a few seconds after start of power latch with the
request of the switch position (LV_STATE_REQ_SWI_PSN_NVLD). In case the switch was open at system
start but closed during the subsequent engine running phase the ?ag LV_DIAG_SMT_SWI_TRAN_NVLD =
1 is set. When this ?ag is set the test ends with no failure. In case the switch was closed from system start
till the beginning of the power latch phase, so LV_DIAG_SMT_SWI_AV_NVLD = 1 and LV_DIAG_SMT_SWI_
TRAN_NVLD = 0, the canister purge valve is commanded open (CPPWM_SP_CPS_NVLD - ->CPPWM_SP_
CPS_EVAP - ->EVAC) for a calibratable time, C_T_CPPWM_CTL_NVLD. When the switch opens as long as

the calibratable time is not reached yet, so LV_DIAG_SMT_SWI_AV_NVLD = 1 - ->0, the test is ended with
?no failure? and the CPS is closed. If the switch did not open during that given time, an error will eventually
be set, LV_ERR_SWI_INT_NVLD (and LV_END_SWI_DIAG_NVLD). Hereafter, the CPS will be closed and, as
this is representing a system error, the ?sleep mode? (see chapter 3.1.1) will be activated.
(The calculation of the PWM set point for the opening of the CPS is done in NVLD plausibility diagnosis
valve control (B09E) and in Valve control coordination manager (B09F)).
ii)Switch check for turbo engines
Due to the presence of mechanical back pressure valves in the purge ?ow system of turbo engines, the
switch rationality check in power latch under i) can not be performed on turbo engines. Instead, the test
has to be done during ?diagnostic mode? before the actual beginning of the small leak check. Normally,
the NVLD checks for switch position, switch closed duration and temperature decrease on its 10 min
wake-up recurrence during ?diagnostic mode?. But on turbo engines, it also measures for temperature
increase (+5�C - ->LV_DIAG_SMT_CDN_5_NVLD) accompanied by opening of the switch (LV_DIAG_SMT_
SWI_OPEN_NVLD). This data is provided during next engine running phase on request (LV_STATE_REQ_
SWI_PSN_VLD) during STATE_NVLD = "SMALL_LEAK_DIAG". But to be able to analyse the response bits,
the bit LC_INH_SWI_DIAG_PWL_NVLD = 1 has to be set before. This will result to the setting of LV_ACT_
SWI_DIAG_NVLD during "SMALL_LEAK_DIAG".
If the switch opened, no matter if the 5�C was present, the non-failure case is set ( LV_ERR_SWI_INT_NVLD
= 0 and LV_END_SWI_DIAG_NVLD = 1). A not-opening with a valid 5�C condition represents the failure case
and will automatically discard small leak test results. If there was no 5�C condition and no opening of the
switch, then no diagnostic on the switch is done. For this case a cancel-?ag is set (LV_CNL_SWI_DIAG_
NVLD). A small leak diagnostic will be done, but the result will not be valid for rate based monitoring.
For i) and ii) the requests and the analysis of the switch are carried out in NVLD plausibility diagnosis
check (B09H). The responses of the status ?ags from NVLD are coming from"Smart sensor communica-
tion for natural vacuum leak detection (I09W)".
f) Check of Small Leak Diagnostic results
The main purpose of the ?diagnostic mode? is to observe the switch position and the duration of the switch
closed time. In parallel, the temperature decrease is also checked by the NVLD on a 10 min recurrence
basis. All this data, so switch closed, switch closing duration and ambient temperature decrease on the
TAM sensor of the NVLD, are monitored and reported to the ECU during next driving cycle. The 6�C or 8�C
temperature decrease (see chapter 3.1.1) and the switch position during diagnostic mode is reported during
STATE_NVLD = "READ_INI" on LV_STATE_REQ_INI_NVLD = 1 request. When the state machine STATE_NVLD
has reached "SMALL_LEAK_DIAG" the closing time duration is requested from NVLD with resulting to the
duration time T_SMT_SWI_CLOSE_RNG [min].
A clear statement for an existing leak in the tank system can only be made if several conditions are ful?lled:
6�C (or 8�C) temperature decrease detected (LV_DIAG_SMT_CDN_6_NVLD), switch did not close during
small leak test in ?diagnostic mode?

A clear statement for an existing leak in the tank system can only be made if several conditions are ful?lled:
6�C (or 8�C) temperature decrease detected (LV_DIAG_SMT_CDN_6_NVLD), switch did not close during
small leak test in ?diagnostic mode? (LV_DIAG_SMT_SWI_CLOSE_NVLD), no other system error present (er-
rors like SMT_RST_NVLD, SWI_EL_NVLD, etc.), switch closing time duration was lower than a threshold (or
0 min) and the absolute difference of the ambient pressure before ?diagnostic mode? to the one at system
start.
A system is declared as tight, when the switch was closed during ?diagnostic mode?, the switch closing
time was greater than a threshold and all other conditions mentioned before for the error case are also
present.
If the switch was closed, and also the closing time duration was ok but the 6�C condition or/and the ambi-
ent pressure condition was not present, then this is leading to a non-failure case as well. But this result is
not counted as a valid result for the Rate Based Monitoring.
In software, the whole small leak check is handled in the modules NVLD plausibility diagnosis manager
(B09G) that sets the requests, in "Smart sensor communication for natural vacuum leak detection (I09W)"
that delivers the status ?ags and in "NVLD plausibility diagnosis check" (B09H) which interprets the small
leak test results.
4. NVLD tasks in ECU power latch and activation of "diagnostic mode" or "sleep mode"
Apart from the fact that for non-turbo engines a switch mechanical check is performed in power latch, this
ECU state is actually solely used to check after certain elapsed time in power latch whether conditions are
given to start a ?diagnostic mode? or to switch the NVLD into ?sleep mode?, so into the non-diagnostic mode

where no measurement of ambient temperature, switch position or any other parameter takes place. Until
this check is done, two things have to happen before in power latch:
a) Locking of power latch
The locking starts at the beginning of the power latch, by setting the bit LV_NVLD_PWL_LOCK. It is released,
when the timer diagnosis (described below in the subitem b) ) and the switch rationality check (see item
3.e) i) ) is ?nished in case non-turbo engine is used and con?gured (LC_INH_SWI_DIAG_PWL_NVLD=0). So
for non-turbo engines this means, that the power latch can be extended till C_T_CPPWM_CTL_NVLD sec
in case the switch does not open. (But normally, the extension lasts only till end of timer diagnosis). When
it?s released, the ?ag LV_NVLD_PWL_LOCK is reset.
The actively controlled power latch extension is necessary to prevent the ECU (software) from shutting
down the system too early and therefore to cancel ongoing switch rationality and timer checks. On the
other hand, this controlled extension of the power latch limits the time in power latch to the absolute
necessary minimum.
[The PWL extension is handled in "NVLD plausibility diagnosis check" (B09H).]
b) Performing of the timer diagnosis
After the locking of the power latch, the timer diagnosis is started. The purpose of this diagnosis is to
synchronize the timer in the NVLD module with the timer in the ECU. As the NVLD has to wake up every
ten minutes for measuring reasons and also has to monitor the switch closed duration time together with
consideration of the maximum time for diagnostic mode (24 h), the alignment of the two timers is an
important parameter.
In software the check for the alignment of the timers is processed in the following way: The diagnosis
begins with the start of an ECU reference timer (T_SMT_REF_NVLD++) and with a request to the NVLD to
deliver the current NVLD time T_SMT_ST_DIAG_NVLD = T_SMT_NVLD, which is the start time value. When
T_SMT_REF_NVLD reaches the calibration threshold C_T_SMT_REF_MIN_NVLD, the reference timer is set
on-hold and the end or stop time (T_SMT_STOP_DIAG_NVLD = T_SMT_NVLD) is requested and gathered
from the NVLD. (Like for the power latch lock extension time, it is also possible that the gathering of the
end time for the timer diagnosis can happen only after C_T_CPPWM_CTL_NVLD sec if a switch rationality
check is ongoing and lasting so long). Hereafter, it is checked whether the reference timer T_SMT_REF_
NVLD is approximately in the same range (<C_T_SMT_DIF_MAX_NVLD) like the difference of the end timer
minus the start timer value, so T_SMT_STOP_DIAG_NVLD - T_SMT_ST_DIAG_NVLD. If not, an error LV_ERR_
T_SMT_INT_NVLD and LV_DIAG_T_SMT_END is set. Subsequently, STATE_NVLD is set to ?SLEEP?, so ?sleep
mode? gets activated.
The timer diagnosis is realized in "NVLD plausibility diagnosis check" (B09H).
c) Decision of activation of ?sleepmode?or ?diagnosticmode?
When timer diagnosis and switch mechanical diagnosis is ?nished in power latch either ?sleep mode?
(STATE_NVLD = ?SLEEP?) or ?diagnostic mode? (STATE_NVLD = ?OFF?) will be activated. In case there is
no system error present, the ambient temperature and ambient pressure are greater than the respective
thresholds (C_TAM_MIN_NVLD, C_AMP_MIN_NVLD) and the communication was not cancelled due to e.g.
low battery voltage supply in power latch, the ?diagnostic mode? will be activated. The activation is re-
quested with LV_STATE_REQ_ST_NVLD.

(STATE_NVLD = ?OFF?) will be activated. In case there is
no system error present, the ambient temperature and ambient pressure are greater than the respective
thresholds (C_TAM_MIN_NVLD, C_AMP_MIN_NVLD) and the communication was not cancelled due to e.g.
low battery voltage supply in power latch, the ?diagnostic mode? will be activated. The activation is re-
quested with LV_STATE_REQ_ST_NVLD. On this request the ECU awaits the response LV_STATE_RESP_ST_
VLD_NVLD which sets eventually LV_DIAG_SMT_VLD_NVLD signalizing the ECU software on next driving
cycle, that all requested data from the NVLD are valid and useable. When any of the conditions are not met,
?sleep mode? gets activated. System failures like T_SMT_NVLD (timer error), SWI_NVLD (switch mechanical
error; but only on non-turbo engines), TAM_SMT_CHK (TAM_SMT crosscheck error), EL_CPS (canister purge
valve el. error), SMT_EL_SCP/SCG/OC_NVLD (el. errors on the line), MEC_OPEN_CPS (mechanical canister
purge errors) and RESP_REP_COMC activate the ?sleep mode? by setting the bit LV_INH_REQ_DIAG_NVLD.
The activation of ?sleep mode? or ?diagnostic mode? is done in "NVLD plausibility diagnosis manager"
(B09G). LV_INH_REQ_DIAG_NVLD de?nition and the detection of low battery supply (LV_VB_CDN_NVLD_
VLD) are described inthe module Evaporative system monitoring for NVLD (Appl. Inc.) (B09B)

Two modules that are also part of the NVLD aggregate, have not been mentioned yet in this chapter.
Their names and purposes are listed below.
- Evaporative system monitoring for NVLD (Appl. Inc.) (B09B)
This module sets up the link to the error manager. That means, internal NVLD diagnostic ?ags like LV_
ERR_T_SMT_INT_NVLD and LV_DIAG_T_SMT_END that are created one of the other NVLD modules, are
used as input in this module. With these inputs, the ?nal diagnostic ?ags (like e.g. LV_ERR_T_SMT_NVLD
and LV_END_DIAG_T_SMT_NVLD) are created and used in the error management.
- Evaporative system monitoring error interface for NVLD (Appl. Inc.) (B09D)
SMALL_LEAK_NVLD and SWI_NVLD are OBD relevant diagnostics that do not run continuously. Because
of this, Rate Based Monitoring data have to be provided which is accomplished with this module. For
the small leak diagnostic, the relevant indicator for numerator / denominator and inhibitor is named
STATE_RBM_EVAP_1/2 and for the switch rationality diagnosis it is named STATE_RBM_CUS_FUC.
For SMALL_LEAK_NVLD, Mode6 data has to be provided as well. The relevant variable for this is the
switch closing time T_SMT_SWI_CLOSE_RNG_SAE which should be in case of error smaller than a calibra-
tion threshold and in the non-failure case greater than the same calibration threshold.

3.1.4 NVLD state ?ow in condensed pseudo code format
Another way to easily understand the working of the NVLD functionality and the interaction between the
different modules and also to learn something about the main important variables used within the function is
to show the NVLD process by the basic state machine and state ?ow of STATE_NVLD.
The following pseudo code part shows standard state machine ?ow beginning from key-on (LV_IGK = 0- - >
1) to engine start (LV_ST_END_NVLD = 0 - - >1), engine running (all the states from READ_INI till WAIT), engine
stop with key-off (LV_PWL = 0- ->1), power latch (LV_PWL = 1) and ?nally power off (ECU not powered).
Each request, so each different STATE_REQ_NVLD = "xxx" (originated from LV_STATE_REQ_xxx_NVLD), needs
about 1,5 sec to be processed so till a response is created. During the standard state machine ?ow there are 11
requests - for Turbo engines there are 12 - processed till small leak results are evaluated and the diagnostic is
done and STATE_NVLD has switched to "WAIT". So in total it takes 17-20 sec.
For better understanding of the pseudo code, a graphical illustration was inserted below. It shows a typical state
?ow of the central state machine STATE_NVLD and the request interpretation (or processing) state machine
STATE_REQ_NVLD. The state ?ow starts from system startcoming from ECU reset. This is important, as system
starts from engine-off due to key-off with a subsequent start of the engine leads to a different "shape" of the
state ?ow. Reason: Once the system has started (coming from ECU reset) and the state machine STATE_
NVLD ?nishes the state "SMALL_LEAK_DIAG", requests for data from ?diagnostic mode? will not be set any
more until a new ?diagnostic mode? is started again. This means, the system needs to be in power latch till at
least STATE_NVLD switches to "OFF".

Reason: Once the system has started (coming from ECU reset) and the state machine STATE_
NVLD ?nishes the state "SMALL_LEAK_DIAG", requests for data from ?diagnostic mode? will not be set any
more until a new ?diagnostic mode? is started again. This means, the system needs to be in power latch till at
least STATE_NVLD switches to "OFF".
So below in the picture the state ?ow starts from system start, followed by an engine running phase of ?20
sec and ends with a power latch phase which eventually starts the diagnostic mode.

3.2 CPS-Check
Like for tank leak check, there are also several methods to run a plausibility check for canister purge valves
installed on combustion engines. The main purpose of this check is to detect a stuck closed valve. It is also
possible to detect stuck open valves but from OBD point of view this is less critical as this means that you
are still able to purge.
The following chapters should on the one hand give a brief overview about the physics and the modules
that built-up the CPS check.
3.2.1 Short introduction to the physics of the CPS-Check
The second task of EVAM on vehicle with gasoline engines consists of the functional check of the canister
purge solenoid, the CPS-Check. The CPS is used to purge the hydrocarbons inside the ACF into the engine
manifold and also, in case for example the vehicle is stopped, to isolate the engine from the tank system
when the CPS is closed. The correct mechanical function of this valve should be diagnosed on each driving
cycle in case conditions are given.
As more and more vehicles have less and less idle speed phases during driving cycles, but especially during
the FTP cycle, CPS checks need to ful?l the requirement to run during engine part load phases. During
File: 30102A04.00A
10517Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
EVAM, EVAM General
these part load phases, disturbances are induced onto the engine system by opening the canister purge
valve in a de?ned way. The system reactions on this ?disturbance? are analysed and used for diagnosis.
In this EVAM aggregate, a part load capable CPS check is described that uses the MAP-Sensor signal for
analysis purposes. The induced ?disturbance? pattern, generated with the opening pattern of the CPS, is
detectable in the MAP-Signal. The degree of coherence of the expected (and therefore calculated) pressure
difference results compared to the measured results on the MAP-signal gives information about the func-
tionality of the CPS-valve.
This method can be used to detect the functionality of the CPS valve and in the same time the functionality
of the purge pipe which is especially interesting in case more than one purge pipe is mounted on the en-
gine. On charged engines this is more and more the case: a second purge inlet before the charger creates
a purge ?ow during overpressure operations. Both purge paths can be diagnosed with this CPS check.
In non-charged operation, the MAP-signal is used and in charged operation an additional pressure sensor
(PRS_CP_PIPE) inside the second purge line is used for analysis purposes.
For more information about this please refer to module B00R.
3.2.2 CPS-Check modules
The CPS-Check in EVAM consists of the following modules:
Functional check canister purge solenoid (B00R)
- Core module for the canister purge solenoid function
- De?nition of Activation condition (LV_DIAGCPS_ACT_DIAGCPS)
- Filtering of input signals (MAP_MES, PRS_CP_PIPE)
- Calculation of degree of coherence between measured and expected values
Functional check canister purge solenoid, apllic. incid. (B017)
- Calculation of Mode6 values
- RBM interface is provided
- De?nition of function inhibition ?ag
- Project speci?c adjustments
- Creation of ?nal error MEC_OPEN_CPS_1/2
Functional check canister purge solenoid EOL(J10D)
- De?nition of activation conditions for CPS check at End Of Line
3.2.3 CPS-Check diagnostic instance: Naming, description and failure causes
The CPS check has only one diagnostic instance:
Failure Detailed information Failure causes
MEC_OPEN_CPS - diagnostic monitors stuck closed and stuck open
canister purge valve
- valve mechanically stuck open or closed
- valve electrically not plugged and el. diagnosis
(EL_CPS) not activated
4. Detailed description for NVLD and CPS-Check
Additional explanations for NVLD and CPS-check, with more information about software variables, their
function and the detailed sequence of the diagnostics are given in the subchapters of the aggregate
EVAM.

37.3.1 Tank leak check system con?guration
� General Information
This section of the Aggregate adaption module for EVAM de?nes which Modules should be called when on
system DMTL or NVLD is con?gured. A distinction was necessary, to be able to run Audi or VAG software
baselines but different leak detection hardware with one software.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at reset:
Note: This action must be called, before NVMY read-out and
before LV_CONF_DMTL check/assignment (os_system_task)
If ACTION_INFR_GetTankLeakTypeInfo = 1
Then
LV_TANK_LEAK_TYPE_DMTL = 0
LV_TANK_LEAK_TYPE_NVLD = 1
Else
LV_TANK_LEAK_TYPE_DMTL = 1
LV_TANK_LEAK_TYPE_NVLD = 0
Endif

Then

(see table below)
Else Tank leak type not configured
Endif
Endif

37.3.2 OBD Radar for EVAM
� General Information
The standard values are calculated for the ?rst time after a completed diagnostic cycle. The end of a diagnostic
cycle is indicated by the DMTL cycle ?ags that are available for each standard value and checked before the
calculation of a new standard value.
A DMTL leck check diagnosis, and therefore a standard value calculation, only runs once, only in PWL and
only if cold start and some more environmental conditions were given. That means, it can happen that the
standard values are not updated during every driving cycle.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at reset:
Bit 0 LF_CUR_DMTL_REF_LEAK_OBDS_VLD = 0
Bit 0 LF_CUR_DMTL_DMTLS_OBDS_VLD = 0
Bit 0 LF_CUR_DMTL_ROUGH_LEAK_OBDS_VLD = 0
Bit 0 LF_CUR_DMTL_SMALL_LEAK_OBDS_VLD = 0
Bit 1 LF_CUR_DMTL_REF_LEAK_OBDS_VLD = 1
Bit 1 LF_CUR_DMTL_DMTLS_OBDS_VLD = 0
Bit 1 LF_CUR_DMTL_ROUGH_LEAK_OBDS_VLD = 0
Bit 1 LF_CUR_DMTL_SMALL_LEAK_OBDS_VLD = 0
Activation: always

� General Information
The purpose is to diagnose the signal from the driver which controls the DMTL solenoid valve (which di-
rects the ?ow either to the tank or the reference leak module part). The failure detection is done by ECU
Hardware (cdn_diag_dmtls & err_diag_dmtls). The diagnosis detects electrical faults as de?ned by OBDI
requirements.
The diagnosis is only activated if DMTL is con?gured.
The diagnosis is adapted to the UDGI error management.

� Function Description
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(NC_FID_ERR_DMTLS, LV_PRMS)
ACTION_INFR_GetElDiagDmtlS(cdn_diag_dmtls, err_diag_dmtls)
IF LV_CONF_DMTL = 1 AND
LV_CDN_VB_OBD1 = 1 AND
LV_FID_READY = 1 AND
LV_PRMS = 1 AND
LV_RLY_MAIN = 1 AND
CTR_PSD_DLY_DMTLS = 0
THEN
IF Bit 0 set of CDN_DIAG_DMTLS
THEN
IF Bit 0 set of ERR_DIAG_DMTLS
THEN LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_SCP = 3
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_SCP = 1
ENDIF
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_SCP = 0
ENDIF
IF Bit 1 set of CDN_DIAG_DMTLS
THEN
IF Bit 1 set of ERR_DIAG_DMTLS
THEN LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_SCG = 3
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_SCG = 1
ENDIF
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_SCG = 0
ENDIF
IF Bit 2 set of CDN_DIAG_DMTLS
THEN
IF Bit 2 set of ERR_DIAG_DMTLS
THEN LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_OC = 3
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_OC = 1
ENDIF
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_OC = 0
ENDIF
ELSE
LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_SCG = 0
LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_OC = 0
LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLS_SCP = 0
CTR_PSD_DLY_DMTLS = CTR_PSD_DLY_DMTLS - 1
ENDIF

� General Information
37.5.1 DMTL pump SCP symptom determination
� General Information
The diagnosis is only activated if DMTL is con?gurated (lv_conf_dmtl = 1)
Due to hardware conditions and overtemperature protection for shunt resistor (max time for SCP is 50
ms) the SCP detection is only possible with monitoring the voltage of V_DMTL. That?s why part of the SCP
detection runs in 10 ms recurrence. The 10 ms functionality generates a bit LV_SYM_0_DMTL_PUMP which
is used to debounce the SCP diagnosis in case of failure.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at igkoff2on:
LV_SYM_0_DMTL_PUMP = 0
T_V_DMTL_MAX_DIAG = 0
Activation: always
Recurrence: 10 ms
� Function Description

IF LV_CONF_DMTL = 1 AND
LV_CDN_VB_OBD1 = 1 AND
LV_FID_READY = 1 AND

LV_RLY_MAIN = 1
THEN
IF LV_DMTL_PUMP = 1 //pump is switched on
THEN
IF V_DMTL > C_V_DMTL_MAX_DIAG

THEN

ELSE

ENDIF
ELSE T_V_DMTL_MAX_DIAG = T_V_DMTL_MAX_DIAG - 10ms
ENDIF
ELSE T_V_DMTL_MAX_DIAG = 0
ENDIF
ELSE T_V_DMTL_MAX_DIAG = 0

� General Information
The purpose is to diagnose the signal from the driver which controls the DMTL heater. The failure detection is
done by ECU Hardware. The diagnosis detects electrical faults as de?ned by OBDI requirements.
The diagnosis is only activated if DMTL is con?gurated.

EVAM, Tank leakage detection heater diagnosis
CTR_PSD_DLY_DMTLH = NC_PSD_DLY_DMTL_EL
Activation: always
Recurrence: 1000 ms
� Function Description
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(NC_FID_ERR_DMTLH, LV_PRMS)
ACTION_INFR_GetElDiagDmtlH(cdn_diag_dmtlh, err_diag_dmtlh)
IF LV_CONF_DMTL = 1 AND
LV_CDN_VB_OBD1 = 1 AND
LV_PRMS = 1 AND
LV_FID_READY = 1 AND
LV_RLY_MAIN = 1 AND
CTR_PSD_DLY_DMTLH = 0
THEN
IF Bit 0 set of CDN_DIAG_DMTLH
THEN
IF Bit 0 set of ERR_DIAG_DMTLH
THEN LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_SCP = 3
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_SCP = 1
ENDIF
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_SCP = 0
ENDIF
IF Bit 1 set of CDN_DIAG_DMTLH
THEN
IF Bit 1 set of ERR_DIAG_DMTLH
THEN LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_SCG = 3
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_SCG = 1
ENDIF
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_SCG = 0
ENDIF
IF Bit 2 set of CDN_DIAG_DMTLH
THEN
IF Bit 2 set of ERR_DIAG_DMTLH
THEN LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_OC = 3
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_OC = 1
ENDIF
ELSE LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_OC = 0
ENDIF
ELSE
LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_SCG = 0
LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_OC = 0
LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_SCP = 0
CTR_PSD_DLY_DMTLH = CTR_PSD_DLY_DMTLH - 1
ENDIF
ACTION_ERRM_ResultDiag (IN<NC_IDX_ERR_DMTLH_SCG>,
IN<LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_SCG>, OUT<STATE_FIL>)
ACTION_ERRM_ResultDiag (IN<NC_IDX_ERR_DMTLH_OC>,
IN<LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_OC>, OUT<STATE_FIL>)
ACTION_ERRM_ResultDiag (IN<NC_IDX_ERR_DMTLH_SCP>,
IN<LF_STATE_DGO_DMTLH_SCP>, OUT<STATE_FIL>)

37.7.2 Operations of the 100ms task
37.7.2.1 Electrical NVLDII switch diagnosis
The function is divided in three parts. In the ?rst part the electrical diagnosis of the NVLD switch during
smart module diagnosis phase is performed. In the second part the electrical diagnosis is performed during
engine-on and in the third part, the activation of part two is calculated.

� General Information
The NVLD smart module communication is realized by the ECU via an output driver. The failure detection is
done by ECU hardware.
The information about the status of the line, ERR_DIAG_SMT_EL_RAW_NVLD and CDN_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD,
are provided by the output driver. These variables are on the one hand used to generate an auxiliary bit
LV_SYM_SMT_EL_NVLD that is used in the communication spec (Module acronym: I09W) to control the com-
munication (request <->response) between ECU and NVLD. Besides the control of the communication, it also
helps identifying errors on the communication.
On the other hand these status variables are used to detect electrical faults on the communication line as
de?ned by OBD I requirements.
37.8.1 Acquisition of Basic Software Diagnosis Information for Communication Diagnosis
Mode
� General Information
The ?ag LV_SYM_SMT_EL_NVLD is not like it might appear on the ?rst view an error symptom indication ?ag,
but a variable that tells the communication part of the NVLD functionality (described in I09W) that messages,
so ground levels on the line, are still transmitted. If a transmitted ground level does not ?t to the request <->
response pattern between the ECU and NVLD, then a communication error is set in I09W. For this purpose,
LV_SYM_SMT_EL_NVLD is used.
In the below functionality, LV_SYM_SMT_EL_NVLD is set to 1 if the communication line is set to ground (ERR_
DIAG_SMT_EL_RAW_NVLD !=0) or, in case this information can not be delivered properly by the ECU hardware
driver, in case conditions for SCG, OC and SCP are set accordingly: Bit 0 (SCP) of CDN_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD = 1,
and bit 1 and 2 for CDN_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD = 0. This signalizes an ongoing communication on the line. Both
con?gurations are selectable by the switch LC_SYM_SMT_CDN_DIAG_INH_NVLD.
To exclude wrong errors due to low battery, the LV_SYM_SMT_EL_NVLD calculation is only active in case the
battery voltage level is high enough.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation:
Activation: always
Recurrence: 10 ms
� Function Description
ACTION_INFR_GetElDiagSmt(OUT <cdn_diag_smt_el_nvld>, OUT
<err_diag_smt_el_raw_nvld>)
If { ERR_DIAG_SMT_EL_RAW_NVLD != 0 or
(bit 0 of CDN_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD = 1 and
bit 1 of CDN_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD = 0 and
bit 2 of CDN_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD = 0 and
LC_SYM_SMT_CDN_DIAG_INH_NVLD = 0) } and
LV_VB_CDN_NVLD = 1
Then LV_SYM_SMT_EL_NVLD = 1
Else LV_SYM_SMT_EL_NVLD = 0
Endif

37.8.2 Determination of Error Symptoms depending on Diagnosis Conditions
� General Information
The error symptoms (SCG, SCP and OC) of SMT_EL_NVLD are detected automatically by the output driver. In
order to avoid wrong SCG detections during communication between ECU and NVLD, so during the period
where communication line is ?intentionally? put to ground level, the SCG detection is deactivated. See setting
of Bit 1 of CDN_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD = 0.
Also, when the battery voltage is too low (LV_VB_CDN_NVLD = 0) or there are system errors present that might
lead to wrong diagnostic results, all symptom diagnostics are inhibited.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at reset and igkoff2on:
CTR_DLY_DPS_SMT_EL_NVLD = NC_PSD_DLY_SMT_EL_NVLD
ABC_SMT_EL_NVLD_SCP/SCG/OC = 0
LV_SYM_SMT_EL_NVLD_SCP/SCG/OC = 0
ACTION_ERRM_Reset(IN <NC_IDX_ERR_SMT_EL_NVLD_SCP/SCG/OC>)
Activation: always
Recurrence: 10 ms

LV_INH_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD = 0 and
[(LV_ECU_RST_DET_NVLD = 0 and //system not in wake-up
LC_SWI_SMT_EL_DIAG_ECU_RST = 1)or
LC_SWI_SMT_EL_DIAG_ECU_RST = 0 ]
Then(1a)
//Case the diagnostic is not inhibited
If(2) CTR_DLY_DPS_SMT_EL_NVLD = 0
Then(2)
If(3) STATE_COMC_NVLD = 2h or // communication ongoing
(STATE_COMC_NVLD = 4h and // communication ongoing
CTR_DIAG_MOD_NVLD > C_CTR_DIAG_MOD_REQ_NVLD)
Then(3) Bit 1 of CDN_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD = 0
Endif(3)
Else(2)
CDN_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD = 0
CTR_DLY_DPS_SMT_EL_NVLD = CTR_DLY_DPS_SMT_EL_NVLD -1
Endif(2)
Else(1a)
//The diagnostic is inhibited, the delay to start the diagnosis is set to
max.
CDN_DIAG_SMT_EL_NVLD = 0
CTR_DLY_DPS_SMT_EL_NVLD = NC_PSD_DLY_SMT_EL_NVLD
Endif(1a)

� General Information
Purpose of the diagnosis
The purpose of the diagnosis is to detect a jamming, opened or closed, canister purge valve (CPS) and to
demonstrate the controllability. The result of the diagnosis shall be disclosed.
Advantages of the redeveloped diagnosis:
? wide diagnosis window in the part load
? reliable results (independent of the driving dynamics and interference signals)
?

The result of the diagnosis shall be disclosed.
Advantages of the redeveloped diagnosis:
? wide diagnosis window in the part load
? reliable results (independent of the driving dynamics and interference signals)
? short diagnosis time and thus a high ratio

EVAM, Functional check canister purge solenoid
Figure 37.10.1: Operating principle with manifold air pressure sensor for intake point in the intake manifold
During the diagnosis, the control from the canister purge is interrupted. A pattern is impressed to the control
signal of the CPS (PWM signal) instead. The pattern can be output by means of a target mass ?ow speci?cation
as well. The effect of the stimulation is measured by means of the manifold air pressure sensor. If the pattern
is not found again by the pressure sensor, then there is a defect in the canister purge system CPS.
The stimulation of the CPS is not disclosed to other functions, for example to the charge sensing. The goal
of the stimulation is to achieve an effect that is suf?cient for the diagnosis without in?uencing other functions
/ controllers or worsening the exhaust-gas characteristics.
In ?gure 1, it can be detected that the pressure signal is ?ltered with a low pass. The difference from the ?ltered
value is determined after that. In this way, pressure oscillations for example are compensated. The pressure
in the CPS line is available for a canister purge system with pressure sensor in the CPS line, in this way the
Ps in the intake manifold is replaced. Other functional parts are: enable and abort of the diagnosis and error
detection as well. In error detection, the average differential pressure amplitude achieved is used in order to
increase the differentiation power between an OK CPS and a not OK CPS.
Correlation analysis
The (cross-)correlation(analysis) is a statistical procedure in which the similarity of two signals is evaluated
mathematically. In this way, dependencies between 2 signals existing in the error free case, can be detected
or veri?ed.
In this way, the dependency for example, between a control signal x and a measured variable y that depends
on this can be veri?ed in the case of an active correlation or, in case of control operations for example, the
dependency of the actual value on the set values can be demonstrated.
The correlation coef?cient CCC is the result of the correlation calculation. The CCC can be between 0 and 1.
0 means: No connection between the signals x and y
1 means: both signals are identical.

Figure 37.10.2: CCC calculation
In the diagnosis, the CPS is stimulated with a test pattern. An expected value x is calculated from the test
pattern, with the consideration of the damping behavior of the CPS supply line. The signal x is compared by
means of correlation analysis with the reaction y of the pressure (e.g. manifold air pressure).
A short, digital signal is used as a test pattern which can be made of up to 20 states (cycles). The states change
in an applicable chronological interval (e.g. after 0.5 s).
At the same time with a state change of the test pattern, the x and y values for the following evaluation are
recorded and the intermediary results of the correlation analysis are calculated.
For the example in ?gure 2 (10 cycles), there are 11 values for x and 11 for y.
Figure 37.10.3: Sampling of the signal curves

The correlation coef?cient is determined after sampling the signals.
Figure 37.10.4: High correlation of the signal curves
In the ?gure above, the y signal is free from superimposed noise components and a very high CC results, close
to 1.
Figure 37.10.5: Low correlation of the signal curves
In the ?gure, a noise signal is superimposed that has the same amplitude as the undisturbed y-signal. A clearly
lower CCC resulted.
Notes to correlation analysis:
? An ampli?cation or a static offset of the signals considered has no effect on the correlation coef?cients.
? Even small phase offsets of two otherwise identical signals can have a detrimental effect on the correla-
tion analysis.
? It is probable to ?nd again another signal (stimulation pattern) within a noisy signal (CCC = 1). This
probability is reduced with the increase of the number of samplings.

EVAM, Functional check canister purge solenoid
Figure 37.10.6: Chronological diagnosis sequence
Phase I:
Veri?cation of the enabling conditions,
CPS-access: Canister purge function
Phase II:
Enabling conditions ful?lled, function readiness outputted, wait for enable by the scheduler
CPS access: Canister purge function
Phase III:
Wait for deactivation, if the enable is made by the scheduler
CPS access: Deactivation function
Phase IV:
CPS deactivated, Elapse of an applicable waiting time
CPS access: Diagnosis function
Phase V:
The request for disabling the fast charging compensation is output and the output of the stimulation pattern
for diagnosis of the CPS, diagnosis result calculation,
CPS access: Diagnosis function
Phase VI:
Diagnosis concluded, enable of the quick charging compensation
CPS access: Canister purge function

37.10.3 Canister purge valve check paths: CL and CPS
The canister purge valve can be diagnosed by two paths:
- CL_CHK, in which the canister load of the char coal ?lter is evaluated and used for diagnosis statement. (Note:
With this path, only working Canister purge valves can be detected!)
- CPS_CHK, in which pressure sensor signals of the intake system are used to detect the functioning of the
canister purge valve. (Here, failure and non-failure detection is possible).

(Note:
With this path, only working Canister purge valves can be detected!)
- CPS_CHK, in which pressure sensor signals of the intake system are used to detect the functioning of the
canister purge valve. (Here, failure and non-failure detection is possible).

37.10.3.1 Canister load check: Overview of in- and outputs
The canister load check is generally activated when the LV_CDN_DIAGCPS_CL_CHK ?ag is set to 1. To accom-
plish this, several boundary and environmental conditions are checked. A switch LC_CL_MMV_CHK_DIAGCPS
allows the activation and deactivation of the CL_CHK by calibration.
When the canister load function is activated, the canister load is checked versus a threshold. The threshold
must be exceeded for a calibration time to achieve the ?nal diagnosis output LV_CL_CHK_DIAGCPS_1/2.
The distinction of the two purge paths, aspiration purging and purging via charger, is done by the ?ag LV_
CDN_DIAGCPS_CHA_MOD.
As long as the diagnosis? were not ?nished in the CPS check path and as long the result ?ags of the CL_CHK
are not set, the function remains active.

37.10.3.2 CPS check (overview)
The instructions of the process with 20ms task can be divided into 3 groups. From a chronological point of
view, they are calculated one after the other.
The state machine STATE_DIAGCPS= 0 corresponds in the sequence diagram to the phases 1 and 6
The state machine STATE_DIAGCPS= 1 corresponds in the sequence diagram to the phases 2, 3 and 4

37.10.3.2.1 Filters and Integrators
As soon as the diagnosis is in the state "standby" or "active", additional variables are calculated for performing
the diagnosis.

The calculated variables are used as function-internal.
Integration:
? Mass ?ow through the CPS for the current canister purge phase
? Mass ?ow through the CPS since engine start for forced activation of the diagnosis

EVAM, Functional check canister purge solenoid
Filtering:
? manifold air pressure
? Pressure in the CPS line
? Modeled manifold air pressure
? Engine speed
? Relative air charging
Difference generation:
? Filtered manifold air pressure and modeled, ?ltered manifold air pressure
? Ambient pressure and ?ltered manifold air pressure
Injection Correction:
Moreover, the function offers the possibility to correct the amount of fuel mass during CPS-Check. The
purpose of this correction is to avoid vehicle jerking because of spontaneous fuel amounts coming from CPS
opening that are not well compensated by lambda control. This jerking is especially critical, when the canister
load is high and stays high because of hot outside temperatures.
The fuel mass injection correction during CPs-check can be enabled by the switch LC_ENA_DIAGCPS_INJ_
COR.

EVAM, Functional check canister purge solenoid
37.10.3.2.1.1 Mass ?ow through CPS
If the canister purge diagnosis is not active (LV_DIAG_MEC_OPEN_CPS_ACT = false), the Integrator determines
the ?ow of air and fuel put through the CPS during the (last) active canister purge phase. This integration is
only active when the purge mass ?ow is above the minimum mass ?ow (C_FLOW_CPS_MIN_MAF_INT_CPS).
As soon as the diagnosis becomes active (LV_DIAG_MEC_OPEN_CPS_ACT = true), the integrator is frozen. By
means of the integration constant, the unit of the ?ow put through MAF_INT_CPS is converted to grams. The
Integrator is reset to 0 when either the command for this is given explicitly (LV_DIAGCPS_BAS_PRM_INI = true),
or when one of the following variables:
? LV_DIAGCPS_CP_ACT = true (canister purging active)
? LV_CL_MMV_CAL_ACT = true (loading calculation active)
? PRS_DIF_AMP_MAP_DIAGCPS >C_PRS_DIF_AMP_MAP_MIN(suction mode)
is not set for at least the C_T_DL Y_RST_MAF_INT_CPS time. Before resetting the integrator, its output value
MAF_INT_CPS is added in the accumulator. From the sum of the current accumulator value and the ?ow that
is currently put through MAF_INT_CPS the ?ow put through since the diagnosis state "off" was left MAF_INT_
CPS_DC is determined. With the change of the diagnosis state "off" to the state "standby", MAF_INT_CPS_DC
and MAF_INT_CPSare reset.
For systems that have a purge path into the charger and therefore have a sensor installed in the purge path
(LV_PRS_SENS_INS_CP_PIPE true), a separate threshold for PRS_DIF_AMP_MAP_DIAGCPS has to be checked
(C_PRS_DIF_AMP_MAP_MIN_CHA_MOD) to enable the conditions for the diagnosis of the second (or charged
mode) purge path (LV_CDN_DIAGCPS_CHA_MOD_ACT true). In case the MAP gets greater than the AMP, PRS_
DIF_AMP_MAP_DIAGCPS becomes negative. Therefore the calibratable constant should be set to negative
values.
This second calibratable threshold is also there to clearly distinguish between non-charged and charged purge
path diagnosis as there are ranges of pressure differences between AMP and MAP where neither the one nor
the other one can be performed.

37.10.3.2.1.2 Filtering of input signals
The ?lters are counted in the diagnosis states "standby" and "active" before calculating the state machine of the
diagnosis. When changing the state from "off" to "standby", the ?lters are initialized once with the current avail-
able values. The modeled manifold air pressure MAP_MDL is ?ltered twice in parallel. The originated manifold
air pressure, modeled and ?ltered, MAP_MDL_FIL_DIAGCPS_1 is used during the diagnosis for a dynamic limita-
tion. The second originated manifold air pressure, modeled and ?ltered,MAP_MDL_FIL_DIAGCPS_2 is used for
calculating the differential pressure PRS_DIF_CP_DIAGCPS to the measured and ?ltered manifold air pressure
MAP_FIL_DIAGCPS . Finally, the differential pressurePRS_DIF_AMP_MAP_DIAGCPS is determined. For the diag-
nosis based on the pressure sensor in the CPS line (L V_PRS_SENS_INS_CP_PIPE=true),the differential pressure
between modeled and measured manifold air pressure is replaced by the differential pressure between the
ambient pressure and the pressure in the CPS line.

37.10.3.2.1.3 Injection correction for CPS-Check: Overview
The injection correction for CPS-Check is structured in three blocks:
INJ_COR_PRE_PRM
Before the start of the actual CPS-Check, the canister load from the purging function is memorized.
File: MCB00R02.00C
10593Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
EVAM, Functional check canister purge solenoid
With the second input from the purging function, FLOW_MAX_CPS, the maximum allowed PWM value for the
CPS valve is calculated. This is to make sure, that the EVAM function does not request more than the purging
function would allow with the current setting and therefore to reduce the probability of jerking.�
T_DL Y_INJ_COR_INI
Depending on the air mass ?ow and the manifold air pressure, delay times are calculated for the non and for
the charged mode. The delay time is necessary to apply the fuel mass correction at the right point of time.
MFF_ADD_DIAGCP
With the memorized canister load and the calculated ?ow setpoint during CPS-Check, the fuel mass correction
is calculated. As soon as the injection delay timer has elapsed, the full fuel mass correction is fully applied as
long as the engagement of the CPS valve (NR_STI_PAT_CPS) is present. When the CPS valve gets closed (NR_
STI_PAT_CPS = 0 or STATE_CPS_DIAGCPS <>2) the fuel mass correction is ramped down with in a ?ltered
way.

37.10.3.2.2 Checks and calculations during STATE_DIAGCPS = "STANDBY"
The state machine of the diagnosis is made of the states "active" ( STATE_DIAGCPS=2), ?standby? (STATE_DI-
AGCPS=1) and "off" (STATE_DIAGCPS=0). The state is stored in STATE_DIAGCPS.
In the state diagnosis "standby", ?rst the enabling conditions for the activation of the diagnosis are considered.
The transitions are veri?ed subsequently.
If the conditions for the switch to "active" are ful?lled, the entry state for the subordinate state machine for
stimulation of the CPS is the state "Initialization". The transition in the state diagnosis "off" is also possible.
37.10.3.2.2.1 Overview of enabling conditions
The enabling condition for activating the diagnosis results from the functional and physical conditions and two
chronological conditions:
L V_CDN_DIAGCPS_PHY_OK
L V_DL Y_ENA_DIAGCPS_AFT_INTR
L V_DL Y_ENA_DIAGCPS_PERM
File: MCB00R02.00C
10598Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE

expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
EVAM, Functional check canister purge solenoid
The time delay of the enableL V_DL Y_ENA_DIAGCPS_PERMappears only when the diagnosis in the application
purposes was shifted in the permanent operation ( L V_ENA_PERM_DIAGCPStrue). If the diagnosis is not in
permanent operation, it is carried out completely only once after the initialization of the ECU.L V_END_DIAGCPS
= true prevents another enable.
The time delay by means of the conditionL V_DL Y_ENA_DIAGCPS_AFT_INTRalways appears after the diagnosis
is aborted. In this way, after a diagnosis is aborted, time is reserved for carrying out the adaption of the AKB
charging state and the charging compensation.

37.10.3.2.2.1.1 Functional enabling conditions
The functional enabling conditionL V_CDN_DIAGCPS_FCT_ALL_OKis generated from several partial conditions.
If there is a short trip request available, some of the partial conditions are not considered or other conditions
are used.

EVAM, Functional check canister purge solenoid
A summary of all the conditions for setting the functional enabling condition can be found below.
1. Valid relative air charge to be ?own based on throttle valve
2. Valid relative air charging ?owing off from the manifold intake
3. Valid allowed working range for diagnosis (see DiagRngNorm and DiagRngShoTrp hierarchy)
4.
a) Rpm
b) Relative air charging
c) Differential pressure ambient pressure and manifold air pressure
5. Rpm-, engine load and manifold air pressure dynamics in the allowed range (see DiagEngDyn)
6. Conditions regarding lambda control are ful?lled (see hierachy DiagLamGov)
7.
a) Lambda in the allowed range
b) The lambda controller is not at the limit stop
c) Lambda controller active
8. Adapted AKB charging state in the allowed range (see DiagFacPurgeAdp hierarchy)
9. The air ?ow put through since engine start is higher than the temperature-dependent threshold
(Temperature since engine start)
Another prerequisite for enabling the diagnosis with regard to the AKB charging state is that this state is within
a valid range (see DiagFacPurgeAdp hierarchy). A forced enable will take place however if the air mass put
through the CPS (see engine start) exceeds the threshold C_MAF_INT_CPS_DC_MIN. The charging state of the
AKB has thus no longer an in?uence on the diagnosis enable. However, the forced enable can be deactivated
as applicative if needed (L V_DEAC_DIAGCPS_MAF_INT_CPStrue).
In the function part "EnaPurgeLn", the diagnosis enable actions for two test paths (intake path directly into the
intake manifold and intake point before compressor) are prepared separately.

37.10.3.2.2.1.1.2 Diagnosis range in the short trip
The allowed charging range for the diagnosis is de?ned by limiting the relative air charging and the differential
pressure between ambient pressure and ?ltered manifold air pressure. In order to consider the combustion
limit, a minimum, rpm-dependent, relative air charging is de?ned in the lower charging range. In the upper
charging range a minimum, rpm-dependent differential pressure is not allowed to be under run. The differential
pressure PRS_DIF_AMP_MAP_DIAGCPS is the current difference between the ambient pressure and the ?ltered
manifold air pressure.
The differential pressure is not checked in case of function request (short trip). Neither does the minimum
threshold for the relative air charging depend on the rpm.

37.10.3.2.2.1.1.3 Enabling condition Engine dynamics
For the engine rpm and the relative air charging, an analysis of the dynamics is carried out. By means of low
pass and subsequent generation of the difference between ?ltered and un?ltered signal, the parts with a higher
frequency are determined. For enabling the diagnosis, the absolute change of the engine rpm must be lower
than C_N_DIAGCPS_GRD_MAX. Likewise, the maximum absolute change C_RATIO_MAF_MAX_COR_GRD_MAX
shall be adhered to for the relative air charging.
Also, the manifold air pressure difference between modelled and measured needs to be below cailbratable
thresholds.

37.10.3.2.2.1.1.4 Enabling condition lambda controller
Because the lambda controller must continue to be active during the diagnosis, the status and the regulation
behavior are checked. The lambda values from both benches must vary within the allowed limits and the
lambda regulations from both benches must be active. A data input pair is explicitly speci?ed for the end-of-
line test so that the data input for the end-of-line test is separated from the driving operation. For the case
when the diagnosis can become active also during cut-off operation, the lambda controller is not considered
in cut-off.

37.10.3.2.2.1.1.5 Veri?cation of the AKB charging state
In order to be able to take into consideration the AKB charging state, the air mass put through the CPS (MAF_
INT_CPS) must ?rst exceed the thresholdC_MAF_INT_CPS_MIN. The veri?cation represents a validity condition
of the adapted charging state CL_MMV. The value of the air mass to be interpreted is reset when leaving the
diagnosis state "off". In order to receive a diagnosis enable, the AKB charging state is not allowed to exceed
a certain value that is part of a hysteresis. The average threshold of this hysteresis depends on the mass
?ow in the intake manifold and the ambient temperature and is determined accordingly via the sub-hierarchy
FlowAdpMax. The hysteresis range can be applied via the parameterC_CL_MAX_DIAGCPS_HYS.

In order to receive a diagnosis enable, the AKB charging state is not allowed to exceed
a certain value that is part of a hysteresis. The average threshold of this hysteresis depends on the mass
?ow in the intake manifold and the ambient temperature and is determined accordingly via the sub-hierarchy
FlowAdpMax. The hysteresis range can be applied via the parameterC_CL_MAX_DIAGCPS_HYS. Moreover, the
maximum opening angle of the CPS and the ratio between the air mass ?ow through the CPS and through
the engine are veri?ed and if the charging is appropriate the diagnosis is enabled. The veri?cations of the
mass ?ow by means of the CPS and of the AKB charging state are thus part of the enable conditions during
normal engine operation, but, by means of short trip request ( L V_EOL_CPStrue) they can be however made
ineffective. In this case it is only veri?ed whether the charging state of the AKB is below the threshold C_CL_
MMV_DIAGCPS_MAX_EOL.

37.10.3.2.2.1.1.6 Enabling condition according to diagnosis path
In this subsystem, the diagnosis enable is distributed to both canister purge intake paths. The cycle ?ag of the
diagnosis for intake point in the intake manifold ( L V_END_DIAG_MEC_OPEN_CPS_1_TMP) and the intake point
before the compressor (L V_END_DIAG_MEC_OPEN_CPS_2_TMP) are used for distributing the diagnosis enable
and in this way it is ensured that every CPS intake path is diagnosed only once in the driving cycle.
Depending on the determined maximum CPPWM value during FLOW_MAX_CPS analysis for fuel mass injec-
tion correction, each of the paths can be deactivated as long as the required minimum PWM values are not
exceeded.
In case the canister load check has already ?nished MEC_OPEN_CPS_1 or MEC_OPEN_CPS_2, the CPS check for
this path will no more be started.

37.10.3.2.2.1.2 Physical enabling conditions
For setting the physical enabling condition L V_CDN_DIAGCPS_PHY_OKthe following conditions shall be ful-
?lled:
? Enable by means of Inhibiter
? External disabling conditions not set
? Ambient pressure sensor value above minimum threshold
? Cooling water temperature (or back-up value) above the limit value
? Ambient temperature above the limit value or function request
? Battery voltage in the allowed range
The Inhibiter controls the enable of diagnosis and the parallel sequence of diagnoses or functions.
(LV_DI_DIAGCPS is an additional condition that must be set to 0 to allow enabling of the CPS check. The ?ag
covers/bundles external disabling conditions. It is de?ned in the applic. incidences for CPS check.)
